content:
ry 13, 2016
 Basic Information:
Genre: Action, Adventure, First-Person.
Developer: Valve.
Publisher: Valve.
Release Date: 19 Apr, 2011.
Story:
The storyline of this game is great. The story isn't short it's a great length story, with very mind blowing test chambers that take time to complete. Portal 2's single-player campaign returns to the labyrinthine Aperture Science facility, an underground complex lorded over by an insane A.I. named GLaDOS. The main character, Chell, is perhaps the only surviving human in the facility. 
Multiplayer:
When you've completed the singleplayer campaign, you're not even halfway through the game, there are tons of levels yet to explore. together with a friend, you will face many new challenges requirering teamwork and good timing.
Gameplay:
While the base foundation of Portal 2 is still the portal puzzling system acquired from the original, many elements have been added that breathe new life into the mechanic. These fresh aspects include lasers which destroy obstacles or energize power outlets in order to help you progress, gels which can be used to coat surfaces and allow you to either speed run, super jump, or portal your way to otherwise unreachable platforms, several different ways to traverse gaps with new bridge types, and much, much more. I noted in my review of the original Portal that I enjoyed the way you could use momentum to launch yourself through portals, and Portal 2 furthers this feature by kicking it up a notch. Prepare to use Portal 2's flawless physics system in some truly awesome ways. The last great aspect of Portal 2's gameplay is of course the puzzling, which is much more complicated (thus more rewarding) and skill taxing than the originals. The only con I can think of as far as gameplay goes is that it can often break up the flow of the narrative if you get confused on a puzzle, and you will. Besides this small grievance, I absolutely believe that Portal 2's gameplay is superb and a great improvement from the original.
Design & Graphics:
The game looks great, it runs well on any modern pc, and the specifications match the performance and graphical output. Really great Graphics for  year 2011.
Audio/Music:
The game sounds great. the OST is nothing special, but it gets the job done in the game. All explosions and sound effects are fine. The voice acting in this game is also great, and the dialogue can be quite funny. 
Controls:
The game uses your standard FPS WASD and mouse controls, but also supports a special razer controller, and Xbox gamepads.
Difficulty:
The game's difficulty depends on your puzzle solving skills. There is no difficulty or hints, should you get stuck and not be able to proceed, then you will need to turn to the internet. I can understand how one would get stumped in this game, with some of the testing chambers being massive. 
Workshop  Support:
thanks to Portal 2's workshop support, everyone who owns the game can make levels very easily and upload them to the workshop for others to play. so if you like the concept of the game but already finished the story, you should definitely check out the workshop.
Pros
 Amazing story. Great Co-op campaign. Steam Workshop Support for a ton of maps. Very nice electronic soundtrack. Consistently clever and challenging puzzles. Great graphics.ConsNone.  Score Rating  9.5/10

content:

What I liked about the game 	Funny and entertaining characters; like Cave Johnson, Wheatley and Glados. 	New items added into the puzzles.   	Plenty of mysterious things to find throughout the game; like Rat man hideouts. 	Portal 2 is twice as long, with plenty of areas to explore. I really liked exploring the old part of Aperture. 	Puzzles get gradually harder, and things change a little when you're in the old part of Aperture.	Steam achievements and extra content. 	Interesting story that takes unexpected turns. What I disliked or was disappointed with 	Still too short. 	Wasn't as keen on the soundtrack this time round. Conclusion Outstanding game; Value managed to pull it off again. Everything I loved about the first game is still there. If you liked the first portal game then I highly recommend you buy this. 94/100

content:
y 14
Product received for free
												ortal 2 is a first-person puzzle game developed and published by Valve and released in April 2011. Portal 2 incorporates a campaign that allows you to solve challenging puzzles while treating you to a strong and simple storyline. This review will discuss the campaign, the voice acting, dialogue, and the co-op feature.Portal 2 is a good and challenging puzzle game that emphasises creativity and excels in the simplicity of telling a story. The story nicely builds to an excellent climax that feels like a satisfying conclusion to the game. The game features beautiful voice acting and some exceptional performances from Merchant and McLain and strongly delivers in the quality of the dialogue. I am new to the puzzle genre so playing Portal 2 felt fresh and different. There are some issues outlined above in the game, but nothing that detracts from the overall experience. At $19.99, I recommend it.Release Date: 19 Apr, 2011The GameplayPortal 2 features a quality campaign that emphasises creativity through overcoming puzzles and excels in superb voice acting that includes funny humour. You begin the campaign as Chell, a female character holding a portal gun. Chell completes tests using her portal gun while being monitored by AI computer system Glados, voiced by Ellen McLain. Chell completes these tests while listening to Wheatley, a programming core that is voiced by Stephen Merchant, in which he wants to escape the facility. The puzzles are diverse and I do not grasp the notion they are repetitive. They do in fact become more difficult as the game progresses which is due to new things being added to each level that add a new layer of complexity. For instance, some levels feature turrets that can spray bullets at you, which you must destroy before advancing. Portal 2 has a really good ending that ends the story with an amazing final mission that mixes both emotion and intensity. Furthermore, the ending smoothly transitions into the credits that completely alter the atmosphere into a beautiful light hearted finale, complete with a song sung by Glados. Briefly, the single player experience does have some annoying glitches with freezing when pressing R for the feedback prompt and frequent crashing via alt tabbing. These two issues had minimal impact on my experience of the game.The GamemodeThe dialogue enhances the single player component by incorporating witty humour with dialogue that provides excellent characterisation to the characters. For instance, events showcase characters change of heart and provide some emotion to their robot personalities. This creates a juxtaposition of humans and robots because the game reveals human traits of emotion, self-interest for personal gain, and relationships with other individuals within Glados and Wheatley, both whom are robots. The voice acting in Portal 2 complement the strong dialogue because individually, Stephen Merchant delivers a memorable and excellent performance for Wheatley by striking different voice tones that match different situations within the game. Meanwhile, Ellen McLain provides a good voice line to showcase the personality and character of Glados. The dialogue and voice acting immediately created a sense of whose a protagonist and antagonist in the simple story of hero vs. villain.The co-op element of Portal 2 provides more levels to lengthen the game. These levels add some exciting fresh dynamics to each level because you have to cooperate with your team mate and depend on the other to complete levels. For instance, I had to stand on a button while my friend flew to the other side of the window to retrieve the block in order to complete the level.All in All Portal 2 is a nice Koop Game!

content:
, 2014
												In a way this game want to teach you something...the cruelty of the humans? the corruption of the power? the importance of the cooperation? the devastating effects due to the abuse of the experimentation? And so on...play to find your point of view about it....But back to business!This game is really really really cool! Based on interactive puzzles this game will make your hours flying away like an airplane directed to the other side of the planet.As the name suggest you have to use portals to move yourself from a point to another, or redirect laser beams, or to move objects...or to throw them....or even to throw yourself!The gameplay is fun, but it will easily put a sad face on you in some parts...and vice versa. The co-op mode is indeed the best one I've ever seen. In this game the co-op mode is FINALLY a true co-op mode (and I will say "co-op mode" another time just because I like to say "co-op mode" today). If you don't talk with your partner, if you don't plan to do stuff at the right time, if you go ahead alone....forget this game...is not for you; if you don't cooperate you will be unable to pass the first co-op level.The fact that this game is even multiplatform compatible means that you can even play it with friend that have this game on PS3. This is a very interesting and good thing.The graphic is indeed good, mostly based on HL2 engine (well...is a Valve game...lol) and the sounds are pretty nice too (funny the music based/created on the laser beams or in other puzzles you have to solve); and the support of the contoller will put a smile on the console's enthusiast.The story is related to the first portal and as I said in the beginning the single player mode is more deeper than a simple game; a very good observer and listener will easy understand what this game wants to tell you...probably in its own way but still it is a message.Overall:Graphics 8/10Sounds 8/10Gameplay 9/10Co-Op Gameplay 10/10Longevity 9/10

												A great sequel to the already popular older game "Portal".A creepy setting with more of a backstory than the first, you meet a "friend" named Wheaty as you both try to escape.After activating (because "turned on" is sexual and strange to say when starting a computer) GladOS or that ♥♥♥♥♥ from the first game, you are literaly flung into testing chambers again as Wheaty tries to break you out. Only to later find out that he is crazy and ends up nearly killing you and GladOS. Through playing this game you learn the secrets behind the company and its founder as you travel into the older parts of the labs.I feel that this Portal has more of a story, while the first game focused more on helplessness and not being in control while being watched. I also feel more connected to this game, getting into this universe and being surprised with the shocking turn of events that take place. Sure, I'm not good with puzzel games, so I had to cheat a little and no clip to get to other parts of the game. (I am special. OK?) I am happy with the end results and the ending (no, I am not telling).Stuff:Sounds: 9/10 - Wheaty and GladOS are amazing in this game, and the sounds help too, the voice acting is great!Soundtrack: 10/10 - Here is a fact, and just youtube it if you don't belive me, aparently the soundtrack is so large and it   changes with the gameplay, it will take years for one song to repeat itself.Graphics: 8/10- Ok, Ok, its getting up there with age, but it is still good. I now feel like I am in some Sci-Fi Lab where crazy ♥♥♥♥ happens.ConTROLLS: 8/10 - Same from last game, left mouse for one portal, right mouse for the other.Story: 10/10 - Some secrets are spilled.Overall: 98/100This was a great game, but a game where I will only play once, because it is so linear. There is no choice. Sure, I may go back a try some puzzels without cheating.Maybe a Portal 3? Please? :)

content:
2, 2016
												Portal 2 is a truely unique puzzle action game which makes great use of a portal gun that can form two seperate portals which would allow the player to traverse the levels.A great sequel to the original Portal game, Portal 2 is a much longer game which features much more complex puzzles and introduces lovable new characters. The voice acting and dialogue in this game is amazingly entertaining and funny, I found myself chuckling multiple time during the game due to the character dialogues! The level design in this game is also great as there were some levels which left me stumped for quite awhile and it took me quite alot of brain power to solve them and that gave me a great feeling after doing so!This game features a co-operative mode which allows players to play with people in your friend list or complete strangers through match-making. There are some form of customization options such as hats in the co-operative mode that can be unlocked through completing the game. There was supposed to be more customization options available in a shop but it has since been discontinued. Trading is also unavailable which is pretty unfortunate as it would be great for players to exchange or sell cosmetics.There is also a level creation tool in this game which allow players to create their own Portal 2 levels and share it online with others by uploading it to the workshop! Several interesting extra content includes a portal 2 comic which serves as a prequel to the game and a super 8 (a pretty old movie by now) interactive game demo.Overall, Portal 2 is a very entertaining game with great puzzles, characters and voice acting. I would give it a 9/10! A must buy if you enjoy action puzzle games!

content:
er 13, 2013
												I could play the various tests again, and again, forever.  You know, if you recommend such a game to someone else they might devote their existence to creating science.  Aperture Science.  From scratch!Oh GLaDOS (and other personality constructs), how you inspire me...What drew me into this game is that this is no real shooter.  In fact, turrets and bombs are the only combat elements in this game.  Your goal: to escape to the surface, i.e. to think your way out of all those tests in the hope that someday the system will let you go.A masterpiece:Puzzles: 10/10.  Workshop items vary, but the core puzzles (Over 60 of them for Single player and co-op modes) are well-made.  Not so hard that you feel like giving up, but not so easy that you feel like you did nothing.  At some point in the game, you'll have to "test on your own recognizance," with almost no visual hints, but by then you should be well-trained in the "science" of Thinking With Portals.Art: 10/10.  On some of the new testing elements, the blue/orange theme is kept.  Additionally, the various test chamber themes seen as the story progresses are memorable.  Fairly visceral, but not to the point where it distracts from the puzzle solving.Sound: 10/10.  The music is incredible, as are the ambient sound/scapes.Storyline: 8/10, although I must say that the behind-the-scenes stuff for Aperture Science is very impressive!Dialog: 10/10.  Memorable lines by all the characters, with humor to match....Physics: 9/10.  You can't be 100% perfect when portals are involved (visually and otherwise), but the algorithms are much improved from the original.Commentary: 9/10.  I miss hearing Ellen McLain's voice when she wasn't GLaDOS (a similar thing goes for all the other voice actors).  Other than that, the developers have truly insightful stuff!Other details depend on what system you're running, as well as the settings you have.And finally, this awesome game as an awesome in-game editor, in addition to being a Source Engine game, so you can create your own puzzles.  Be sure to check out the Portal 2 Authoring Tools (not for the faint of mind, though).Recommended gameplay (but I recommend playing the original Portal first): Start with Single-player mode.  Then move on to co-op and the developer commentary (for continuity of the story line).  Finally, when you feel tired of the 112 standard maps contained within the game, take a look into the workshop, where you'll find hundreds and hundreds of tests.Overall rating, with some generous rounding: 10/10.  These are also the same odds that you should enjoy this game.Update for Thanksgiving 2016: get nominated for the Test of Time award.  5 years and counting and this game is still one of the best games in the history of great games.

content:
er 27, 2014
Welcome back to Aperture Science(Now with 10% more potato)TL;DR:While singleplayer is a simple and straightforward sequel to Portal, the second installment has a good replay value of its own as it features a variety of extra content, such as a co-op player campaign, plenty of user-generated puzzles as it allows the player some creative freedom in making their own challenges via the ingame puzzlemaker, and there are at least two available story-driven campaign addons on Steam. Portal 2 carries forth the the core likable elements from the predecessor in a charning, quirky sequel.OverviewPortal 2 is a sci-fi physics FPS-puzzle game taking place in a chronologically-ambiguous position in the Half-Life universe. Following the events unfolded in Portal, the sequel brings the faces old and new to the player between the continuity of the experiment courses. It has an entertaining cooperative mode to enjoy with a friend, and user-generated content from the "Perpetual Testing Initiative" that brings the inner mad scientist of the user to life with the ingame Puzzlemaker.PlotTaking the place of the test subject "Chell" once more, the player accompanies her journey through the now-ruined Aperture Science facilities, meeting an old enemy and new faces along the way while solving the various puzzle challenges through the Enrichment Center's remains. The game also features some exploration of the past of Aperture Science, solving some possible loose ends and letting them know about the past of the lab complex. A dark humor-packed character development is noticeable between the messages left behind, and the new quirky characters introduced into the game.The co-op mode also reveals some details of Aperture through the portal experiment course between the two players.Singleplayer ModeThe singleplayer mode is considerably similar to the first game's mechanics, though with a number of twists. New testing elements and various new puzzle-solving techniques make the player think, move and portal their way through the tests with trial and error, either involving the classic testing elements such as moving platforms, turrets and acid pits, or new elements such as lasers and redirection cubes, crusher plates, catapult plates, among others.Cooperative ModeWithout some cooperation the players won't advance in this mode. (Literally. You really can't even get past the level selection if the players don't cooperate and play in such manner.) More advanced puzzle techniques such as timing and advanced portal placement are introduced with a fair amount of trust being in the hands of the partner player. The incompetence (or mischievousness) of either of the parts might end in hilarious failure results.GraphicsUsing an upgraded Source Engine, the game is able to render great-looking environments at relatively low performance cost. Highly detailed testing environments, from the ruins of Old Aperture to the production lines of the upper facilities, you'll see yourself stopping for a few moments to admire the scenery on the areas with more visible attention to detail.Music and SoundThe soundtrack of Portal 2 and its iconic eeriness, generally accompanied by the 'robotic' sounds inserted into the music tracks make Mike Morasky's work fit perfectly into the game.The sound effects of the game, not unlike the soundtrack, are highly detailed. From the slight noises of the testing elements to the rampaging avalanche brought by things like crusher plates in the game, every sound aspect has a high level of detail.The voice acting is priceless, the character dialogue (or, in most part, monologue) is now fitting to each character's personalities and role. Including names such as J. K. Simmons, Stephen Merchant and Ellen McLain, Portal 2's VA cast is noteworthy in that regard.Content CreationAperture Science's Perpetual Testing Initiative -better known as the Ingame Puzzlemaker- is a tool both simple and intuictive to use. Simple controls and a range of elements available, the player can build test chambers to his heart's content with the tool. You can even export your maps to edit with the Portal 2 SDK, for further detailings like custom assets and elements.ConclusionPortal 2 is worth picking up if you're a fan of puzzle games, sci-fi or some quirky humor. The co-op mode warrants some hours of fun with friends, and the puzzlemaker and user-generated content will assure you some extra replay value.

content:
, 2016
Video Game Review: Portal 2Genre: PuzzlePlayer modes: Singleplayer, Co-opView: First-person (third-person omnicient in additional level editor)Content: 29/30Introduction/Tutorial: 5/5A short introduction, which perfectly blends in with the plot, instructs the player on the basic movements and introduces the game's characteristics for a first impression.Plot: 5/5The very original plot continues the Portal series' storyline and surprises with dramatic twists. Duration: 5/5In comparison to its predecessor, Portal 2 exploits it's full potential with just enough variety in elements and plot to extend the singleplayer and co-op campaigns to an enjoyable duration.Characters: 5/5The few yet very important and influentual characters present brilliant dialogues and characteristics. It is notable that the player gets to empathize strongly with entirely robotic characters, which are able to express their emotions in great variety and passion.Difficulty: 4/5The puzzles (which are creatively presented as "test chambers") slowly gain difficulty and new elements during both the singleplayer and the co-op campaigns up to a point where the player is required to recall all of those element's functions and figure out the test chamber's structures. The difficulty of the singleplayer campaign has a slightly lesser increase than expected, in return for adding more dramatic sequences.Menu: 5/5The menu is clearly structured as well as easy to use and to orientate within. It is presented in an appealing design that matches perfectly to the game's theme.Gameplay: 15/15Controls: 5/5The controls are as simple and standart as they need be and entirely customizable in the menu's options.Mechanics: 5/5The physical properties of the player and the objects in the game are realistic and the facility's techniqual equipment moves in an interesting and futuristic manner.HUD: 5/5The HUD interface is kept very simple and presents all necessary information as minimalistic as possible. It is set well not to distract the player and to let them concentrate on solving the test chambers.Design: 20/20Style: 5/5Every piece of the game's environment and elements holds to another in an astonishing and unique way. The style of the facility and the shape of each object represent futuristic technology and create a breathtaking impression of scientific accomplishments.Colors: 5/5The facility's color scheme is set in simple grey tones, concentrating the accents on the vital elements that are connected to emotions, such as the individual characters and the natural environment of the past.Textures: 5/5The textures used in Portal 2 show an impressive development in comparison to other video games that use the Source Engine, driving out its full potential and ensuring the fantastic experience of enjoying the game.Fonts: 5/5The fonts used for the title, menu, and various textures appear as both appealing and serious, reflecting the sincerity of solving important tests for scientific experiments. They are easy to read and kept in appreciable sizes in most cases. Sequences that present an older part of the facility include posters with more lively, curved fonts that remind of the central 20th century.Graphics: 13/15Resolution: 5/5The choices of resolution available in the menu's options include a satisfying maximum resolution of 1980 x 1080 in high definition, which shows a good example for a video game released in 2012.Quality: 4/5The visuals present high quality as well as brilliant shading and lighting in most cases. The setting can fall into deep, vision-restricting darkness at few situations.Performance: 4/5The game usually runs smoothly and without complications. The performance can be optimized at will. Occasionally, the game may crash and return to the desktop during the introduction, which has been the case for me several times. I could easily fix the matter by uninstalling and reinstalling the game without losing any save data, but I couldn't figure out the explanation behind the crashes yet.Audio: 19/20Soundtrack: 5/5The artists on the soundtrack, especially Mike Morasky and Jonathan Coulton, have done an excellent job at accompanying the intensity and depth of the game's plot and visuals with a great amount of epic, unique and inspiring tracks, using an uncommon and perfectly matching genre of music. The instruments and melodies can represent both harmony and disorder individually and usually even seem to interact with the game's environment.Voice Acting: 5/5The fantastically entertaining and usually humorous dialogues and monologues are performed very lively and inspiring. Each voice actor has shown their full potential and let their character develop and express their emotions movingly enough to remember them well.Effects: 5/5The game presents a great variety of sound effects that exceeds the ones of previous games that use the Source Engine, including many individual effects for the technical equipment of the facility. They support the game's very realistic impression.Subtitles: 4/5The subtitles function that is available in the menu's options generally matches the game's style well and show the full dialogue and monologue parts. However, it tends to fill a larger part of the screen when the spoken sequence is notably longer than an average sequence.Conclusion: 96/100Overall Score: 10/10

content:
er 18, 2014
												This game is a masterpiece. It's story and puzzles are out of the park. If you only buy one game, ever, it should be this.Story:This game takes place in a run-down version of the aperture labs seen in the first game. But, unlike it's predecessor, you are helped along by a sphere named wheatley. As you try to escape, you end up waking GLaDoS, the antagonist from the first game, and you are thrown back into full testing. It's now up to you alone to escape.This game's story is very deep and intricate, with nods to the Borealis in some easter eggs, and even the direct mention of black mesa. It has characters with immensly deep and suprisingly dark backstories, and is a game I contemplate still to this day.Puzzles:The puzzles are much more difficult than the first game, and less hand-holding than before. It introduces some nice new testing elements, as well as makes new use of the old ones. The puzzles never end, either, thanks to the "Perpetual Testing Initiative" (Level editor + Custom levels on the workshop). The co-op puzzles double the fun, and difficulty, resulting in a massive need for teamwork. Graphics:The game is suprisingly beautiful, for running on a game engine from the turn of the century. It's lighting and shadows outmatch other popular games, and they don't kill your system. My computer can run this game at medium settings, and my graphics card is an Intel Integrated Graphics HD 4000 (Planning on building a PC soon, using a laptop). It's still a good looking game, and will probably hold up for a while.Audio:This game's music is always there, whether ambiently in the background, or boosting your pulse as you run through broken halls, death on your tail. The music is actually availiable free on their website, 3 full albums with all of the music included in the game.Multiplayer:This game's co-op is brilliant, with customization of the two robots "Atlas" and "P-Body". Using the ping system to coordinate, you don't even need a microphone to communicate with someone random you meet. It even has a bit of story to the game, with the last level group revealing a large secret. The custom levels recentley updated to allow multiplayer, so this dosen't end for a while.In conclusion, the game has a ton of nice features, content, and is really worth the $20 USD, if you are a first time player. I'm planning on getting a few more copies when it goes on sale to hand out to my friends that don't already own it, and play through with them. I love this game, and it's what got me back into PC gaming.

												Portal 2 is an amazing game. If you are considering getting the game, the only problem is that you don't own it yet. The story is completely unforgetable, the gameplay is completely unique, and the puzzles are addicting. The Coop campaign is amazing and really makes you and your friend work together in a way that no other game can require. After you have played the singleplayer and/or multiplayer campaigns, there are an infinite amount of custom chambers you can play, and you can also get carried away with creating your own custom chambers. The game has a really simple level designer, where you can create puzzles almost as complecated as you want for either one or two players. I have played over 2 and a half thousand hours of this game, and I am still enjoying creating and playing custom chambers almost every week.

												Portal 2 is a very, VERY excellent game. Being the sequel to the GOTY Portal, I was expecting it to not be as good. But, upon starting and playing the game, I realized I was immensly wrong. The setting is immersive the moment you see it, and it still has the fun, portal-based puzzle style to it. With the addition of many more mechanics (gels, lightbridges, etc.) this game provides many hours of fun and thinking. The ever present GLaDOS is much more cold-hearted, but with the addition of Wheatly, Portal 2 still has the wit and charm of the first game. If you have played the first game, this is a MUST-HAVE. If you are new to the series, get it, and see how you like it. Adding together the awesome story, and a multiplayer option that makes both you and a friend of your choice either succeed or argue together, this game definitley worth more than the $20 it is being sold for. 10/10.

Grease and flour two 9 inch, round, cake pans; cover bottoms with waxed paper.2.In a large bowl, combine flour, 2 cups sugar, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. Add eggs, milk, oil, and 1 tablespoon vanilla; beat until well blended. Pour batter into prepared pans.3.Bake for 35 minutes, or until wooden toothpick inserted in centers comes out clean. Cool layers in pans on wire racks 10 minutes. Loosen edges, and remove to racks to cool completely.4.Drain cherries, reserving 1/2 cup juice. Combine reserved juice, cherries, 1 cup sugar and cornstarch in a 2 quart saucepan. Cook over low heat until thickened, stirring constantly. Stir in 1 teaspoon vanilla. Cool before using.5.Combine whipping cream and confectioner's sugar in a chilled medium bowl. Beat with an electric mixer at high speed until stiff peaks form.6.With long serrated knife, split each cake layer horizontally in half. Tear one split layer into crumbs; set aside. Reserve 1 1/2 cups Frosting for decorating cake; set aside. Gently brush loose crumbs off top and side of each cake layer with pasty brush or hands. To assemble, place one cake layer on cake plate. Spread with 1 cup frosting; top with 3/4 cup cherry topping. Top with second cake layer; repeat layers of frosting and cherry topping. Top with third cake layer. Frost side of cake. Pat reserved crumbs onto frosting on side of cake. Spoon reserved frosting into pastry bag fitted with star decorator tip. Pipe around top and bottom edges of cake. Spoon remaining cherry topping onto top of cake.

content:
r 31, 2014
												This game carries on the legacy of the first Portal game by introducing new gameplay elements, mechanics and characters. Portal 2 is a masterpiece that is satisfying to play and makes once again stepping into the shoes (or rather, Long Fall Boots) of Chell a very fun experience. With a singleplayer and co-op campaign, the game is a huge improvement on the original and even puzzle and physics-based games as a whole. Having accidentely awakened GLaDOS after defeating her in the first game, Chell is given a new Portal Gun and begins testing once again under the watchful eye of GLaDOS. Along with a new Personality Core called Wheatley, the two travel through the test chambers, hoping to find an exit from the hell that is Aperture Science.With new testing elements such as a tractor beam that can push and pull objects based on what direction it's going, blue gel that makes surfaces bouncy, and aerial faith plates which launch you into the air, Portal 2 makes coming back to Aperture Science a fun, refreshing experience. The puzzles in the first one were basic and limited to cubes, energy pellets and Turrets, but those were extremely fun and this game builds on the already great mechanics.Storyline wise, it's basic, but it works! There's one particular plot twist in it that will catch you by surprise, and the characters and voice acting in this game are just amazing, in every sense of the word. I found GLaDOS to be an excellent villian that had a very good sense of passive-aggressiveness toward Chell, Wheatley to be a fun character that was delightful to see everytime (P.S. he reminds of an actually funny version of C-3PO), and frankly I just enjoyed what the game had to offer in terms of character development.Overall, you most definitely should get this. Excellent in every way possible, though there's not a lot of replay value. That's ok, because you can make and play test chambers created by and other players for brand-new problem solving.10/10

content:
ry 23
												The way I found this game was through people playing it on Youtube, this may have spoiled the main plot points, but it gives different opinions on the game, and those opinions were good ones, as when I played the game myself, I loved every moment of it.Chapter 1 handled the introduction of 2 characters (the player themselves and the personality core/sphere Wheatley) well, and was a good tutorial for players who haven't seen/played the previous game. As well as this, the (re)introduction of GLaDOS was done well, and sets the players the tone for how the next segment will go.Chapter 2 was a good introduction back into GLaDOS' test chambers, and had lower difficulty as it was still near the start of the game. It gives introductions on how the Emancipation Grills/'Fizzlers' work and can be used as testing elements. It also introduces brand new testing elements to this game: Lasers/Laser Redirection Cubes and Aerial Faith Plates. These elements are given equal introductions, and are simple to pick up on.Chapter 3 introduces a third testing element: (after some advanced tests using Aerial Faith Plates) Hard Light Bridges. The way that they are used in its introductory chamber is to cross a large pit that is full of toxic goo. Later on, they are used to block Turret fire, which is a creative way to use them. Speaking of Turret fire, this chapter also re-introduces us to the adorable things known as Turrets. They act just like in the first game, and are still as innocent as they used to be. Chapter 4 continues using mixtures of Lasers/Redirection Cubes, Aerial Faith Plates and Hard Light Bridges in it's test chambers. Then, during Chamber 21, the Personality Core 'Wheatley' finds you and helps you escape from the chamber. With the best-worst imitation of an accent I've heard.During this segment, GLaDOS gives you the 'final' test chamber. (Including a heart on the wall! I mean, how could you say no to that!)Chapter 5 sees you go behind the scenes of Aperture, as you sabotage the only weapons that GLaDOS can use against you: Turrets and 'Deadly' Neurotoxin. I liked this part especially because it shows the inner workings of the facility, and how big Aperture really is. It also has some good dialogue too.[THE NEXT PART CONTAINS SPOILERS FOR THE MAIN PLOT/CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT THROUGH THE SECOND HALF OF THE GAME]At the end of Chapter 5, the plot (and Wheatley) decides that the game isn't over yet, and brings you (literally) falling down to Chapter 6.Chapter 6 and 7 are interesting chambers, because you not only have to use portals and puzzle elements in the chambers themselves, but to get from chamber-to-chamber. The new testing elements of the three Gels was interesting, but I feel like Conversion Gel (White) is 'broken' when you use it in the PeTI (Chamber Building) because when you put it into a chamber you know that people will over use it.Story-wise, these chapters give a backstory to GLaDOS, and how she was made. Which was a nice addition. The puzzles, I feel, had a difficulty spike here, mostly in between chambers, when you have to get to the next Testing Sphere.Chapter 8... Chapter 8. Back in 'modern' Aperture and Wheatley's sheer idiocy has basically sent the facility into meltdown. The chapter shows just how the mainframe has changed him, and most of his dialogue is humorous. He's still evil though. The chapter introduces Excursion Funnels, which are used to move vertically, across gaps (in this case, bottomless pits) and to push buttons that are on the walls and ceilings. Oh, and Frankenturrets: two Turrets fused to a Storage Cube, which are the basic cube for this chapter instead of the regular Storage Cubes. (They're admittedly cute, and I wouldn't mind having a real one.)Chapter 9: 'The Part Where He Kills You'. Dragged the title out, a little bit (GLaDOS and Wheatley's dialogue,  the achievement and the soundtrack title all variants of the title) but it was funny the first time. This Chapter is the final one, and is basically an escape sequence where Wheatley throws EVERYTHING at you. There are two parts where you have to be quick with portals, which the game switches round if you shoot the wrong one, which is very kind. Also introduces Bombs. They'll be useful later.Also contains my favourite quote of the gameFinally, the Boss Fight and Credits: The boss fight was done well, using some of the elements from earlier in the game. And bombs. (Told you they'd be useful)I was fine with the difficulty of the boss fight, but it only uses the Gels, and nothing else. I would have liked to see some other testing elements in there, like Hard Light Bridges or Excursion Funnels, but the Gels were worked well into this part, so I'll let it slide for now.The credits were courtesy, once again, of Ellen McLain, and her wonderful singing. Nothing more to add than, in short, this game deserves the awards it's won, and is one of the best games I've played in a while.Oh, and the Co-Op mode is fun to play after the main game.It's own small campaigns are unique and add some information as to what GLaDOS did after Chell left. Nice touch Valve.

content:
20, 2011
												Game of the year, and screw you if you think otherwise.  Both the single player and co-op games have exceeded all my expectations.  The single player story reaches up to 8 hours of play this time around, offering jaw dropping environments and a LOT more complex portal puzzles with a dozen new elements sure to put even the most clever of players through their paces.  The brilliant writing is back, piecing together the mystery behind Aperture Labs through observing the scenery and of course, enjoying the extremely hilarious lines brought about by pre-recorded PA messages before the disaster, and the dialogue from the few main characters.  Finally, the co-op mode makes full, clever use of both players that's sure to keep you and your friend glued to the game for extended periods of time.  Aside from little replay value, I can't think of a single complaint beyond that.  This is the most fun you will have with a game for a long time.

												I finally got around to beating Portal 2. It was a great one. Once more Valve manages to provide flawless and fun gameplay with great narrative and storytelling, I admire the fact that in most of their games the main character doesn't speak. It still looks and feels great, even after almost 3 years after its release. It is fun both in single player and cooperative online multiplayer. There's tons of mods and user made maps out there so there's alot to play. If you're looking for a casual game to play with a friend or just by yourself there's no way in the world that you will go wrong with Portal 2, it's the sequel to one of the greatest first person puzzle games of all time.

content:
ber 14, 2015
Time to Think Outside the CubeThis is a great puzzle game that makes you think outside of the cube. The tutorial gives you the foundations of how to play the game but after that you are left to your own devices to figure out how to reach the exit. The visuals are somewhat simplistic but they do however look great as they suit the setting that the game is in. If the single-player experience wasn't already anough to buy this game then the co-op experience definitely is. Playing with a friend to solve puzzles can be great fun but also very frustrating but enjoyable at times. However there isn't much replayability in terms of the single-player and multi-player puzzles because once you have done them you have the solution to do it again without thinking. Definitely get this game if you are into puzzles!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 28
												Where do I start? From the moment I started playing this game, I was intrigued as to what was going to happen. Portal 2 has a much bigger and fleshed-out story than the first Portal, and is much more intersting. You're not just a test subject for a breakthrough in science anymore: you're a test subject who just wants to get out of GladOS's reach and be free.Wheatley, the robot who helps you through the some of the game, adds a fun, light-hearted element to the story, and fills in those awkward silences you had when looking for escape in the first Portal. The introduction of co-op was nice aswell, as I always enjoy yelling at my frineds if they do something wrong.I also like the workshop compatibilty, as it adds a lot of extra content to the game, as what I found with Portal 1 was that you completed the story and advanced chambers, and then you had nothing else to do. It also allows the community to show how they think with portals.Overall, a huge improvement on the first game, wiht a lot more content to immerse yourself in. The story is bigger and better, the co-op is huge fun and the workshop compatibility is a great addition.9/10 would think with portals again - I would give it 10 if we got Half Life 3, or Portal 3, or maybe even a second Orange Box with HL3 AND Portal 3? COME ON VALVE, LISTEN TO YOUR COMMUNITY!!!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
16, 2016
 Portal 2 ReviewWhat kind of game is this? How do you play? What do you do? Portal 2 is a FPS puzzle game. It is a direct sequel of Portal 1, and has many similarities to it. However, portal 2 is not the kind of game to sit there and copy what its predecessor did. Absolutely not, it’s here to improve on its past and give you an even better experience then last timeControlsThe game uses your standard FPS WASD and mouse controls, but also supports a special razer controller, and Xbox gamepads 10/10SoundThe game sounds great. the OST is nothing special, but it gets the job done in the game. All explosions and sound effects are fine. The voice acting in this game is also great, and the dialogue can be quite funny. 10/10GraphicsThe game looks great, it runs well on any modern pc, and the specs match the performance and graphical output. 10/10DifficultyThe game's difficulty depends on your puzzle solving skills. Personally, I got through fine without a walkthrough, but I know others who have gotten stuck at points. There is no difficulty or hints, should you get stuck and not be able to proceed, then you will need to turn to the internet. I can understand how one would get stumped in this game, with some of the testing chambers being massive. and i wish valve would have put in a hint button for new or younger players. But in my experience, i got through just fine. 8/10StoryThe story picks up right after portal. X amount of years have passed and Chell must once again be tested. There are several new characters to the series, which it needed. It also manages the bridge the gap between the Half-life and Portal series. I had no issues with the story, and was impressed to see how clever valve was at linking things, and giving background. 9/10 Multiplayer A new feature in Portal 2 is the ability to play 2player co-op testing chambers together. This has no real story to it, but takes place directly after the single player campaign. It's very enjoyable to play portal with a friend, and because of the emote commands, you won’t need a mic, or even a chat box really.  10/10 Length Both the single and multiplayer game modes can be completed in about 10hours total. That’s too short to make this game worth buying unless it’s on sale, Luckily, valve has opened the community to map making, which means, now the game is basically endless. There will always be another community level to play, but not all of them are good. 8/10 Overall Portal 2 is a must have for every steam library. Delivering 2 decent story modes, and endless community levels, you’re in for a good time. You will get to build on the half-life universe, and have a few good laughs while you’re at it. 9/10 - Near Perfect

y 17, 2016
												Portal 2 is alike the first Portal game retaining all the mechanics and aspects of the game you already liked and adds more content into every single possible aspect. More levels, more story, more humour, more puzzle mechanics, more atmosphere, more achievements and more campaign modes to play in (AKA the new co-op mode). The singeplayer campaign is a blast to go through with the intriguing story, witty dialogue and puzzles thats are tons of fun and the co-op is just as fun as you use the things you learnt in singeplayer for co-op but expanding on much more possibilites on level design with the use of four portals as apposed to two. What I love about this game so much is how even when I'm stuck in the game I still have fun using my brain to figure the level out and there's no other game that comes to mind that is so consistently fun even in situations when confused on what to do. If you do not have this game I really, really, really, really, really recommend you do, it's my second favourite game of all time and my absolute favourite game on my Steam library.

content:
, 2014
Does Portal 2 live up to my expectations?Well, the first Portal was a challenging logic puzzle game, with lotsa sarcasm and irony on top. I enjoyed the game very much, but personally didn't (in general) like some of the faster paced reaction bits or having to place Portals while upside down and backwards (though they weren't going to hard on that). Portal had about 70% logic and 30% reaction puzzles aka Test Chambers. Only downturn was, that the (intentionally) grey and sterile environment kept the girls away from playing.So, this game adds some Cockney speaking companion, has the old fun bits, remains solid in the core and adds really wonderful new gimmicks. All of them are lovely, but the Gels "stick" out for me, because they open up incredible possibilities. Apart from the gels, the game is in general more colourful than its predecessor since the story after the end of Portal allows that. Now it is about 80-90% logic puzzles which are not just recycled old ideas. To the contrary, the game hasn't really maxed out the sheer endless options and this is there the community comes in.This is about one of the biggest games ever, since there are hundreds of free community test chambers to download and easily to integrate which makes the game extremely valuable - not only on sale!Sadly, there are more of these factory/outdoor debris maps, where most effort remains simply looking for the portable surface. The icing on the cake is the Co-Op Multiplayer, which should be really part of any good workplace team building effort. This hypes the game to a complete new level. Portal 2 reassures the community that Valve stands for witty quality games.Highly recommend this game; don't see anything worse compared to Portal and most of it better. You don't need to play the first part, but it helps to enjoy some comments even the better.

content:
y 18, 2012
												In my opinion this is the greatest franchise Valve has ever come out with.This game in its entirety is genius to me; the whole concept is just amazing. It has mind boggling puzzles that are extremely creative (which now you can make your own with steamworks), and an amazing plotline with a real cinematic feeling to it when it comes to the cut scenes. There’s one scene that gives me a chill every time, and that in itself is amazing.For a puzzle game it sure does feel like there is a lot of action in this game. It can be very fast paced at times, and slow paced at others. Which I like, it’s nice to be stood there for ages thinking so hard at one point and running around franticly trying not to die at another.There’s an amazing set of characters which are so perfectly done in terms of voice acting. I really couldn’t think of any better match for the characters they came up with. It has awesome little secrets and things to find that really expand your curiosity even further and make you really want to know more about the goings on at Aperture Science Laboratories. The humour in this game is wonderful, and there was more than a few times I had a real chuckle to myself, I was pretty impressed with how well it was done.There is a lot to this game, and it really is one of the best gaming experiences I have ever had.You are a test subject, and you are once again trying to find your way out. But a lot stands in your way.I was pretty sad when I finished this game, as I’m not sure there’s anything to go on to turn into a future game. If there is, bring it on. I would love to once again be thrown into this world, but sadly I doubt there will be. It’s an amazing franchise, definitely one I can see myself playing again in future.There is also a comic online on the Portal website for anyone that would like to see a beautifully constructed comic with some wonderful art that fills in some gaps and shows you how Aperture Science got to be how it is today.

content:
18, 2014
												I got Portal 2 the week it came out on the xbox, and beat the campaign, and co-op (Including co-op dlc) many times. Once I got a coupon for the pc version, I knew I had to get it. I am so glad I did.Graphics: 9.2Gameplay: 10Story/Lore: 9.5Controls (Keyboard) 10Controls (Controller) 10BONUS: Secrets: 10Total: 9.78In Portal 2, you play as the mute, Chell, as you try to escape from the testing labs of Aperture Science. But not everything goes according to plan.Graphics: Being a game from '11, this game looks absoultely beautiful. It's stunning. It looks like a 2013 game, really.Gameplay: The gameplay is like no other game. The puzzles, although a tad bit confusing at points, is a ton of fun. The addition of the gels make for a great time.Story/Lore: Now I'm going to do this one without spoilers, Going to be hard. In this game, you discover the truth of Aperture Science, the truth about Glados, and (if you look closely) some truth about why you are there. They dont just slap you in the face about it, they make you think about it.Controls (Keyboard): The keyboard controls are great. Nothing else to say.Controls (Controller): If you have a Xbox360 controller, and can connect it, do it. This game becomes 200% better with a controller.Secrets: This game has some of the greatest hidden secrets in the game, ranging from crossing into other games, to more information behind characters, to going back and jumping to your death.

content:
er 27, 2014
												I totally recommend this game for you to buy.This is a FPS puzzle game with a lot of physics in it.I love the challenging puzzles and It's really a hell lot of fun when I played this game co-op with my friend.The single player also has an interesting story and it will keep you playing for hours trying to solve the puzzles.The Co-Op mode is epic.The people who designed the level are true geniuses.I'm surprised how demanding the puzzles is to work together with your "Partner in Science".For example,you have to help open portals from the other side of the map,activate a button in the same time,help your friend gain momentum to jump to your portal,pass boxes to open doors,etc.If you have a friend that shares the same love of solving puzzles and physics,you'll get a really fun experience from this game,even though you WILL get bored after a couple of hours of gameplay since the game has no replay value.But the experience you get during the progress wil totally worth it.Best puzzle game ever 10/10.Buy it.

content:
13, 2014
												It baffles me as to why I haven't reviewed this yet. I've owned it for almost two years, and I've even created maps for it, albiet terrible ones. It's an amazing first-person puzzle game which offers players a chance to push their brains to the limits. And that's only the Singleplayer. For even more excitement, you can do the Co-Operative campaign, which offers an even tougher experience, as you need both players'... cooperation. Both stories are as amazing as the puzzles, so even if you find the puzzles easy, you can at least enjoy the story. And, again, even if you don't enjoy the story, there are literally thousands of community created levels from you to choose from, each with a certain theme. While most offer the 'Into the Multiverse' theme, narrated by the Aperture founder and CEO himself, others can have their own complex storyline and theme. I'd give this game a 10/10 rating. If you buy it, you'll likely get one of the best games on the market.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												Portal 2 is a masterpiece, a work of art that you will love for its ingenious story pop-culture, references to logical puzzles and co-op multiplayer. Definitely a candidate for game of the year.Sporting some of the best writing and voice work in years (as well as some deviously designed puzzles), Portal 2's single-player campaign is superior to its predecessor in every way. It makes the original look like the prototype it was. It's filled with a larger cast of characters vividly brought to life through brilliant writing and some of the best voice acting in video games.Impatience aside, Portal 2 is an exceptionally well-crafted, intelligent, entertaining, humorous game. You will laugh. You will feel like a freaking genius. You will want more. And yes, you will probably be hearing quotes from Portal 2 for the next three years.

YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Portal 2 

			Views: 78		

			Portal 2 is a puzzle physic games available here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/620/ Join us at Twitter or Facebook if that is your thing: https://twitter.com/TheSocioPsycho...		

Portal 2 is a first person puzzle game with excellent physics challenges.It is a second part of the story from the first Portal game.  The narratoris dry and sarcastic, and very funny, and the story is well done; it helpsyou propel through the game even when you are stumped by whatever puzzleyou may be working on.The game performs smoothly, with will done level design.  The puzzlesare based off of manipulating the levels with a portal gun, as well asusing gravity and physics when necessary.  The difficulty and level designprogress in a balanced way, and does a great job of leading you in a linearfashion, but leaving you to solve the puzzles on your own.  Awareness ofthe details of the map is key.For someone who likes puzzle games, this is an easy recommend.This is a summary of what I talk about in the video I am a YT'er not a blogger.Thanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

content:
8, 2015
												Play the first Portal entry before you play this one! You won't appreciate the first game if you don't as it's still a true classic.Portal 2 takes everything that makes the original title so amazing, and expands. This game is everything in the first game, but more, and with loads of bells and whistles to make it a brand new installment, and leaves just as big an impact; which is remarkable considering that Portal broke many boundaries itself. Innovation is a good way of describing this game. With more, cleverly designed puzzles, a greater story, and even more memorable characters, this is an absolute must for an Steam owner. A virtually flawless game with tonnes of content besides the main story, with a Co-op, a test chamber workshop, you'll have plenty of hours of fun with this one! Valve truely outdid themselves with this title. Buy it now!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2015
												Interesting, stimulating, and strangely addictive, this game is a first person (adventure?) puzzle with single player and a 2-player co-op option. At first, I found it a bit mind boggling but once I got the hang of it, could not help but go to the next level and the next. I love how the co-op is really a cooperative effort whereby you and your partner each play a role and no one can pass a co-op level without the other. Set in a dreary landscape of what seems to be a futuristic post apocalyptic world, it is fun and engaging, although I would recommend that you laugh off anything GLaDOS has to say and don't take any of its sarcastic and degrading commentary to heart. I also find myself wanting the ability to make Portals in real life. Can anyone here help create it? All in all, enjoyable torment. =)

content:
ry 14, 2016
												>plays co-op with sister>i do all thinking work and tell her where to put portals>GLaDOS tells us that im smart and did all the work and that my sister didn't do anything10/10 would laugh at my sister getting roasted by GLaDOS againBut seriously now:OMFG I DON'T EVEN KNOW HOW I SHOULD WRITE THIS ------------------------------------------------------------------Most games bore me, frankly. But this game, a very repetitive game where you just use portals over portals, kept me addicted the whole way through. This probably is the second Steam game I was interested in enough to beat. Some areas were a bit harder to solve (probably because my brain can't function well at 4am), so I just went to bed, and the next day I'd try again, and beat it. The game's puzzles are perfectly balanced in difficulty, and the story itself is a big reason to play this game. Trust me, the ending is well worth it. REALLY...really...worth it.And please, for your sake, do NOT look up walkthroughs. It will completely ruin your gaming experience.P.S.: Take off a few hours, and that's how long it took me to beat story mode. (Play time was 11.7 hours when I wrote this)P.P.S.: This was my first ever review, so yes, it probably isn't in-depth enough, but I hope I got my main points across.TL;DRThis game's ending is worth the play, not to say all the puzzles and...dem feelz.

content:
7, 2012
Portal 2 — блистательная, остроумная, исполненная с удивительным чувством вкуса и меры игра.Парадоксальным образом большая часть хвалебных возгласов отведена критике. Но это критика восторженных, бесконечно влюбленных в Portal людей. Это критика тех, кто прошел Portal не как запойный алкоголик, за уик-энд, а растягивал удовольствие неделями. Это критика тех, кто летом 2010-го по три раза ходил на одну и ту же E3-презентацию, а затем пересказывал ее коллегам в баре. Portal 2 — это, безусловно, ПОБЕДА. Несмотря на все голливудские ужимки, безупречный юмор и возмужавший геймплей, Portal 2 остался герметичным набором пазлов, театральной научно-фантастической пьесой от первого лица. Но любим мы его от этого ничуть не меньше.+ ОТЛИЧНЫЙ СЮЖЕТ+ ПРЕЖНЯЯ МЕХАНИКА ДОПОЛНЕНАЯ НОВЫМИ КРАСКАМИ+ ВЕЛИКОЛЕПНЫЙ ТЕАТРАЛЬНЫЙ ЮМОР+ КООПЕРАТИВ- КОНЦОВКА ДАЕТ ПОНЯТЬ, ЧТО ПРОДОЛЖЕНИЯ НЕ БУДЕТ

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 24, 2014
												Let me start off by saying I don't like playing puzzle games. I'm not great at them to begin with, and they frustrate me sometimes.Portal pretty much changed my outlook on that. I'd known about the Portal games for quite a long time before actually playing them. The first game was a great start, but I did wish there could have been more substance.Portal 2 is the embodiment of the perfect sequel. The gameplay improves greatly from the first; the chambers feature more factors, like the gels, hard light bridges, etc., and feel much more challenging. And, if you somehow get bored of the main Portal 2 campaign, there's also co-op!Storyline-wise, it exceeded my already high expectations. The dialogue was usually witty (GLaDOS), hilarious (Wheatley), or both. While there were very few characters in this game, it did a good job of making them complex and interesting. Of course, there are still some loose ends in the plot that were purposely left out, but I feel like it was better off being vague.Portal 2 definitely lives up to its reputation. After all, it takes a lot to be featured in hundreds of easter eggs across the video gaming universe.

content:
er 24, 2014
												Portal 1 was a bran new style of game using a new puzzle gimmick the portal.  Though while it was interesting, exciting and original, it did not feel like a complete game, but more like a demo.  Portal 2 took the ideas of the original and pushed the limits into a full fledged game.  With new puzzle items like jump panels, different gel types (i.e. speed boost and jump boost), light tunnels, a new co-op gameplay option and a much more intense storyline, this sequel sets a new standard for sequels.  The puzzles can go from absolutely simple to quite complex, but nothing too outside of the box that you will be completely stuck.  I thoroughly enjoyed this game and highly recommend it to all.

content:
ber 26, 2011
												I have played the original Portal before playing this and Portal 2 was a must buy for me. And it didn't disappoint.Likes:- 100% player and camera control from game start to game end except for the ending scene. Zero cutscenes. This is what an ideal PC game should be. This point might seem very weird but it is a very big and important point in PC gaming- Not too easy, not too hard either. Lots of 'aha' moments. For those who don't know, the 'aha' moment is the defining characteristic of this game. If you don't get that feeling you can't appreciate the gameplay- Great use of sound- Music rhymes with gameplay- Great writing and entertaining story- Great voice acting- Co-op doesnt feel like it was added, it was made- Great FREE DLC. Usually free doesn't mean great. But Portal 2's DLC was surprisingly great.- Community made maps and mods- Can be played by all age groups- PolishedDislikes :- Source Engine is getting oldVerdict : 94/100Don't let the genre stop you from playing this game

content:
er 21, 2013
												The sequel to 2007's Game of the Year, and this time there are whole new challenges to complete.Once again it is set in Aperture laboratries, with the maniacal GLaDOS (Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System) trying to kill you as you complete test chambers.Singleplayer campaignChell (the character you play as) wakes up in an Aperture relaxation vault, and a robotic voice asks you to do certain actions. This is by far one of the best tutorials I have ever seen, as it manages to add this stage somewhat into the story. You head back to bed and are woken up again after what the computer states as "9-9-9-9-9-9-9... years", to find someone knocking on the door. You open it and find a small robot sphere named Wheatley, and this is where the real journey begins.Multiplayer (or co-operative) campaignYou play as one of two robots, Atlas or P-body; with your partner playing as the other. It is set after the singleplayer campaign, and challenges you to think in an entirely different way. It features the same testing elements, but completely new test chambers. Unfortunately, when playing co-op on Mac or PC, you require a friend who also has bought Portal 2 to play this mode (unless you have a controller, but split-screen on a computer monitor is awful). WARNING: you're co-op partner may (highly likely) have a habit of dying. A lot.Unlike Portal, Portal 2 has a much longer story and a more complicated plot. But don't let this scare you, as the plot has only a few things going on at a time.Also, there are many new testing elements, such as:- Hard-light bridges- Excursion funnels- Thermal discouragement beams- Aerial faith plates- Repulsion gel- Propulsion gel- and conversion gelI thoroughly enjoyed this game, and it has plenty of things to make you come back, like hidden secrets and achievements, and a level editor that lets you create your own test chambers using many of the features available.For a list of Portal 2's many awards, go here[thinkwithportals.com].The official website of Portal 2 is http://thinkwithportals.com.

content:
7, 2012
Portal 2 — блистательная, остроумная, исполненная с удивительным чувством вкуса и меры игра.Парадоксальным образом большая часть хвалебных возгласов отведена критике. Но это критика восторженных, бесконечно влюбленных в Portal людей. Это критика тех, кто прошел Portal не как запойный алкоголик, за уик-энд, а растягивал удовольствие неделями. Это критика тех, кто летом 2010-го по три раза ходил на одну и ту же E3-презентацию, а затем пересказывал ее коллегам в баре. Portal 2 — это, безусловно, ПОБЕДА. Несмотря на все голливудские ужимки, безупречный юмор и возмужавший геймплей, Portal 2 остался герметичным набором пазлов, театральной научно-фантастической пьесой от первого лица. Но любим мы его от этого ничуть не меньше.+ ОТЛИЧНЫЙ СЮЖЕТ+ ПРЕЖНЯЯ МЕХАНИКА ДОПОЛНЕНАЯ НОВЫМИ КРАСКАМИ+ ВЕЛИКОЛЕПНЫЙ ТЕАТРАЛЬНЫЙ ЮМОР+ КООПЕРАТИВ- КОНЦОВКА ДАЕТ ПОНЯТЬ, ЧТО ПРОДОЛЖЕНИЯ НЕ БУДЕТ

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 24, 2014
												Let me start off by saying I don't like playing puzzle games. I'm not great at them to begin with, and they frustrate me sometimes.Portal pretty much changed my outlook on that. I'd known about the Portal games for quite a long time before actually playing them. The first game was a great start, but I did wish there could have been more substance.Portal 2 is the embodiment of the perfect sequel. The gameplay improves greatly from the first; the chambers feature more factors, like the gels, hard light bridges, etc., and feel much more challenging. And, if you somehow get bored of the main Portal 2 campaign, there's also co-op!Storyline-wise, it exceeded my already high expectations. The dialogue was usually witty (GLaDOS), hilarious (Wheatley), or both. While there were very few characters in this game, it did a good job of making them complex and interesting. Of course, there are still some loose ends in the plot that were purposely left out, but I feel like it was better off being vague.Portal 2 definitely lives up to its reputation. After all, it takes a lot to be featured in hundreds of easter eggs across the video gaming universe.

content:
y 6, 2014
												After the surprising success of Portal, here comes the sequel. The game opens with Chell back in Apature Science after being freed by a bumbling core named Wheatly. After accidentally rebooting GLaDOS, Chell is back with the Portal Gun and going through another round of tests until Wheatly comes in to save her again. Will they be able to stop GLaDOS again? Or is there another core that is more destructive then her? The gameplay is like before, lots of puzzle solving while relying on your Portal Gun to help out, the puzzles are more challenging this time. While ya havethe portal gun and the companion cube, you also have Gels that come in handy. The Blue Gel lets you jump higher, the Orange Gel makes you run faster, and the White Gel makes you put portals anywhere. There are also light bridges, lasers and tunnes that help out with the puzzles, while ocasionaly outsmarting Turrets. Instaed of one character talking to you, you have 2 that do most of the talking in this game. GLaDOS is still the GLaDOS we know and love while Wheatly is the hilarious clumsy Core who clearly states that he's not a moron. There's also a 2 player Co-op mode where 2 robots from Apature take in on GLaDOS's tests, I've only played the PS3 version of this and it's fun toplay when you have a buddy helping out. So if you liked the first game, then your goingto love the sequel, full of surprises, complicated puzzles, and whitty dailouge. The game is a fitting ending to Portal that it makes you wonder how can they top it off with a Portal 3? Well then again Valve can't count to 3. lol

												Let me say first-hand that this is one of the best games I have ever played.Not only does the game offer a completely unique gameplay style, not only are the graphics bold and fresh, not only is the plot captivating and heartfelt, not only does the game incorporate crude humor (and who doesn't love crude humor, am I right?), not only is the game filled with more action than one would expect from a puzzle game, but it is also full of unforgettable, unimaginable, inmeasurably intense moments of incredible euphoria at knowing that you have beaten a puzzle and that the world is at your fingertips.The introduction serves well to show this - I personally have never heard so many satiric comments in one place in my life. The graphics are absolutely AMAZING, and unlike many other games (Ride to Hell: Retribution anyone?), the storyline actually makes sense. The intensity wrapping grows fairly slowly throughout the game, but that's just a personal opinion.

content:
0, 2012
-Quick Review-Portal2 is a first person puzzle game developed by Valve and released 2011. This game was greatly anticipated when it was announced and we all waited in anticipation for the release.The game was not a disappointment, the developers brought us back to Aperture Laboratories and put us to work on new and innovative puzzles, Portal1 and 2 will always be one of my most favorite puzzle games, period.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: You wake up in a strange hotel-looking room, after awakening you discover you're actually still inside Aperture Laboratories and the whole place is falling apart! You need to find a way out and escape before the whole lab falls down around your ears!Gameplay: The whole game is based on the core concepts of two portals (an Orange/red and Blue Portal), be it moving objects through these portals, moving yourself between these portals, or jumping off high objects to reach hard to reach places, the game is a brainteaser in such a wonderful way. As the catchphrase goes “prepare to think with portals”.There are a number of features in Portal2, there are Single player, Co-op, Community Test Chambers/Workshop, Steam Achievements, and challenge modes where you can compete against your friends for fastest times, least portals used, steps, and more. Achievements: There are 51 Achievements for Portal2, Most of the single player achievements are straightforward fun and challenging to get... There are also Co-op achievements, so it would be best to make or get a friend to help you out.Price: Portal2 is priced at $19.99 that will be the best 20 dollars you spend. But if you're on a tight budget like me you might want to wait for a 75% off sale, since the game was released in 2011 there's a very good chance that there will be sale for it.Conclusion: I really can't sum up how great Portal2 is without saying “look, if you're even remotely interested in trying it out, you don't grasp just what an outstanding puzzle game it is. I highly recommend Portal2 to everyone and anyone.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update September 13, 2015:Here's the URL to see my review for  Portal

content:
er 4, 2013
												Portal 2 is a good game worth playing. Let me say that first and foremost. Yes, if you have the money and are considering getting it, you should.However, if you haven't played Portal 1, play that instead. While Portal 2 has more puzzles and better graphics, I don't think it's a better game. The average puzzle in Portal 1 has 4-8 solutions, and the tutorial puzzles show enough that you learn how to use the mechanics, without making you feel like you're being told how to play. Portal 2 takes the subtle parts that made the first game a masterpiece and sort of hamhandles them. The average puzzle in Portal 2 has 1-3 solutions. The introduction of new mechanics, such as the goop, initially makes for more interesting puzzles, but ultimately creates a need to make the puzzles more restrictive and less intuitive. I didn't finish the game. I am an avid puzzle gamer, but one puzzle near the end of the game required such precision, timing, and execution that I couldn't manage it with the level of awareness I had. Of course, being a very social gamer, a friend and I flew through the multiplayer maps with no difficulty. I think I will attribute that to the lack of goop.TL:DR good game, the first one was better

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 7, 2013
												This is one of my favorite games of all time. A lot of you might think that the original Portal is better, but from what I've seen, it doesn't look any better than Portal 2. Then again, I haven't played it yet.The story of Portal 2 is simple. After what happens in Portal, you wake up in a room that you find out is a containment facility (like the original game, but more... roomy.) After being there for a really long time, your mental state has suffered a lot. However, because there is nobody taking care of Aperture science, the state of the laboratory has suffered as well. Your motives in Portal 2 constantly change, and the story takes many twists and turns while you're playing. This keeps the story fresh and entertaining as you progress, which is a great thing as the story of Portal 2 is important (mostly because of what happens in the first game.)Portal 2, for a game that came out in 2011, looks really polished and has a great visual atmosphere. You can see the effects your actions in the first game have caused in the first 10 minutes of the game, and it's a constant theme throughout the game. Like the story, the visual asthetic has many twists and turns, but key objects stay consistant. This gives you a clear direction of what to do in the game, while also giving you a fresh new canvas to look at.The gameplay in Portal 2 has been improved upon from Portal, not changed. Key features are the same, but new features give the game life and give people who loved the first game a reason to play through the second one. This game has a very megaman-esque feel when it comes to game mechanics. When a new mechanic is introduced, it's usually in an environment that is very lenient so you can learn how that mechanic works. Once the game feels you're ready, it gives you challenges that involve that game mechanic that get progressively harder. Even after beating this game 4 times, I still get stumped on some puzzles. THAT is good game design.All in all, Portal 2 is a masterpiece of a game. There is something for everyone in this game, and I fully recommend buying this at full price. Quick note, I haven't really touched Multiplayer or the level editor.

content:
ber 6, 2015
												Although the mechanics are the same as the first title with only a few additions, Portal 2 still feels like a completely different sort of game than the first Portal.The first Portal was short lived and very focused. Although there were some secrets and deviations the formula for Portal remained only compartmentalized puzzle solving, in a very controlled environment.Although this is still a puzzle game, it feels far less structured and controlled, allowing more room for experimentation and giving you less direction on how you are to complete certain objectives.It's also far longer than the first game, and with a much bigger focus on story.The story in the first Portal was excellent, and a big reason why it was so popular, but regardless, it wasn't the story that was driving the game forward, rather the sense of progression.This game, however, is entirely story driven. Levels are introduced along with the charactes that direct you in those levels, and the atmosphere of each area is unique to the narrative of the characters who are with you in each section.You want to complete puzzles in this game in order to learn more about the world, rather than you learning more about the world as you complete the puzzles.While I love this change, many people might miss the hyper-focused nature of the first game.If you're into the lore of the series Portal 2 is an absolutely wonderful game.If you're more focused on the gameplay, Portal 2 is still a wonderful game, although you may be disappointed by the amount of "fluff" that's present this time around.

I would prefer playing it with a friend instead of a random strangerSteam Workshop: 10/10 - By far my favorite part of Portal 2 is that you can download test chambers created by the communityGraphics: 8/10 - Who plays for the graphics?Needless to say, this game is very fun. Try it out

content:
y 4, 2014
												Portal 2 follows up with the same game mechanics as Portal but this time adds in a full single player campaign. Once you're done with single player there is another lengthy co-op campaign, and once you're done with that there are a few bonus co-op DLC levels included called Art Therapy. This game gets you scratching your head on how to solve complex puzzles but starts off with simple puzzles so you can get used to the mechanics and various game elements. Highly recommended, and nothing beats the feeling you get once you solve a chamber that has been stumping you for awhile. Lastly, thanks to the Steam Workshop there are an infinite amount of community made chambers waiting for you.
